newsitem.title: FRENCH GUIANA: Ariane rocket launch delayed.
newsitem.headline: Ariane rocket launch delayed.

text.p: A technical problem aboard Western Europe's 93rd Ariane rocket has delayed its scheduled January 28 launch for two days, space officials said on Monday.
"During the Flight 93 preparation campaign in Kourou (French Guiana), a Helium leakage was detected on a ground system equipment," the Paris-based Arianespace company said in a statement.

"In compliance with its strict quality control policy, Arianespace decided to replace the connecting plate on the liquid hydrogen umbilical arm. This will now lead to a launch during the night of January 30 to 31, 1997," it said.

The Ariane-4 rocket is scheduled to launch the American GE-2 satellite built by Lockheed Martin Astro Space for California-based GE American Communications and Argentina's first telecommunications satellite NAHUEL-1A for the Buenos Aires-based company Nahuelsat
The Ariane rocket series is launched from the European Space Agency (ESA) centre in Kourou, French Guiana on the northeast coast of South America.
Arianespace leads the commercial satellite launch market and successfully placed into orbit 15 heavy satellites in 1996 aboard 10 Ariane rockets.
The company said its launch backlog is 42 satellites worth an estimated $3.5 billion.
